issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body: I am not yet sure in what sense key attestation is used in the draft. I think you mean workload attestation instead? Particularly the key in Confidential Computing does not exist at initial measurement time (load-time measurement), and hence I think the key -- per se -- cannot be "attested".

issues.title: Separate Client-Side Attester?
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body: What does it mean to have a "Separate Client-Side Attester" in Background-Check model? If the TLS connection terminates outside of Attester, there are trivial attacks possible (e.g., in case of Confidential Computing).

issues.title: Coverage of the measurements/evidence
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
The draft (maybe in Sec Considerations) should say that not only does the TLS stack need to be covered by measurements, but also:

1. The code that performs the post-handshake phase must be measured, and...
2. There must be no other way to initiate generation of evidence except from signed code.

issues.title: Security Considerations: session resumption
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
Discussion with @yaronf, @thomas-fossati , @ionut-arm and Carsten: 

For Sec. 4.1. in draft-00 (Using the TLS Connection): 

**Background**: If the session drops due to some reason, one can do session resumption rather than complete handshake. 
**Problem**: There can be problems in session resumption if remote attestation has not already been done for that session. 
**Solution**:
First remote attestation MUST be done right after the initial handshake. This reduces the problem to essentially 1 round-trip time (for sending Authenticator Request and getting Authenticator) plus time for generation of Evidence and appraisal of Evidence. 

The next rounds of remote attestation can be done on need basis.

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body:
Possible solution to avoid the race condition:
* Establish the handshake with explicit flags that prevent session resumption. (From the client side this can simply mean: delete the ticket before the handshake is complete.)
* Do remote attestation.
* Then enable session resumption. (Send a new `NewSessionTicket`.)

From a TLS handshake perspective this is possible. The question is whether APIs (specifically the OpenSSL API) support these operations and/or can be extended to do so.

issues.title: Terminology: EK in CertificateVerify
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
In RATS interim, Deb mentioned that ephemeral key in CertificateVerify for Authenticator is confusing. 
Clarify the terminology such that it does not contradict TLS.

More context: [interim notes](https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-interim-2025-rats-01-rats#740---755-Identity-Crisis-in-Attested-TLS-for-Confidential-Computing)

We should define EK upfront in the terminology section.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
I like Deb's proposal of defining EK as "self-asserted" and saying the proof of possession is typically provided by self-signed cert. 

So define it like: 

- LTK = CA-certified Long-Term Key (used for server "authentication")
- EK = self-asserted Ephemeral Key (used for remote attestation)

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
Summary of discussion with @thomas-fossati, @ionut-arm and @tireddy2 (Please correct if I get something wrong and add if I missed something)

With Realm Personalization Value (RPV), it may be possible to identify the Realm. Hence, it may be possible to get rid of `EK` altogether. Post-handshake CertificateVerify message will then use the `LTK` as usual. 

All of this is under the assumption that `LTK` has been provisioned to the TEE.

issues.title: Security consideration: Relay attack
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
What prevents a malicious Attester from relaying the `certificate_request_context` to a genuine TEE and presenting the Evidence of that genuine TEE?
This question is not specific to `certificate_request_context` but applies in general to the draft (i.e., also to nonce, timestamp, epoch markers etc.).

Tiru's proposal: (discussed [here](https://github.com/tls-attestation/exported-attestation/pull/12#issuecomment-2844582521))
> one possible technique could be that the verifier will have to enforce policies that ensure the TEE producing the evidence is the one it expects, not just any valid TEE.

pulls.title: More security considerations
pulls.author: yaronf
pulls.body: This is not very polished, but there are security considerations to do with attestation at the application level.

pulls.title: Remove trailing space - get lint to pass
pulls.author: yaronf

comments.body:
```suggestion
This document inherits the security considerations of RFC 9261 and RFC 9334. The integrity of the exported authenticators must be guaranteed, and any failure in validating Evidence SHOULD be treated as a fatal error in the communication channel. Additionally, in order to benefit from remote attestation, it is recommended that Evidence MUST be protected using dedicated attestation keys chaining back to a trust anchor. This trust anchor will typically be provided by the hardware manufacturer.
```
we either recommend or require.  doing both is confusing.

I will go for the latter. In my analysis, once the TIK is lost, an unprotected (e.g., unsigned) evidence is available to the adversary. Hence, remote attestation does not bring any security benefit in this case. One might argue it is even worse than standard TLS because using ephemeral key breaks the authentication property as well (something still to be argued more formally).
makes sense to require.
